sp.p: Sorry, why ſo?

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: Becauſe, charmed as I am with the brilliant ſcenes before me, I wou'd not purchaſe them with the loſs of either.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: May I renounce the pleaſures of Italy, if the girls brain is not turned!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I beg pardon for my company; but Miſs, if you pleaſe, I want to ſpeak a few words to you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: Speak to me?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Yes, Miſs, if you'll go down ſtairs I'll tell it you.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: You had better ſpare her that trouble, friend, by telling it here.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: May hap I won't, tho'—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: You may let it alone then; but the lady ſhall not ſtir, ſo get along about your buſineſs, fellow.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: But I ſay ſhe ſhall, and let me ſee who'll hinder her.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Who'll hinder her?—I, you ſcoundrel—

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Will you?—We'll try that—

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: Hold, Ralph—for heaven's ſake, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Oh, Miſs, I have found it all out!—I overheard the whole ſtory in the kitchen—they are all in a plot to murder and raviſh you and I and Miſs Maria, and keep us here for ever, ſo come along and let us find out maſter.

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb
sp.p: Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Impoſſible, indeed, Miſs, the fool's drunk.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Drunk! no, nor mad neither, and I will have you out, Miſs, or die for it.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: That you ſhall, villain!—

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Nay, you have miſtaken your man, I believe—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Help! murder! help!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Get up again, you ſhall have fair play.

sp.speaker: Epi.—(on the ground)—
sp.p: Curſe your play—help! murder! help!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I fancy you'll not be in a hurry to meddle with a bit of Yorkſhire ſtuff again.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: What's the meaning of all this noiſe and violence?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Aſk him there, he has more reaſon to tell you than I.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p:
By all that's deviliſh, Promiſe, that barbarian had nigh put an end to my being—Keep him off till I get away—I thought him a tool, but if ever I am
again deceived, may I ſuffer tenfold what I have done now!

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: Oh, my Lord, I beg of you to unfold this myſtery, my ſervant ſays there is a plot formed to detain us here.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: There is, Madam—Nay, ſtart not—'tis time to undeceive you—I have now no intereſt in letting you continue longer in your error—Thererfore view every object in its proper light—

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: Gracious goodneſs! where will this end!

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: This houſe you are cloſe confined in, without a poſſibility of eſcape—As a confirmation, advance, Madam, no longer Lady Fanny Promiſe, but Miſs Spence for the future.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Ay, I thought what it would all come to—I'll be hang'd if I did not.

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: I am ſo overwhelm'd with ſurpriſe and aſtoniſhment, that I know not what to ſay.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Miſs Lambton, you are ſafe for the preſent, that lady will attend you into another room—As for this champion who ſignaliſed himſelf ſo valiantly in your defence, he may be troubleſome—convey him into the ſtreet, he'll improve his talent, and meet with plenty of adventures there.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Ay, but two words to that bargain—you muſt have my leave firſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: Stop, Ralph—Surely, my Lord, my ſervant's fidelity ought not to ſubject him to ill uſage. I will rely upon your honour for my ſafety here, and hope you will extend it to him.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Miſs Lambton, I pity your confuſion, and will not ſtay to encreaſe it—Diſmiſs your fears—Let your ſervant retire—he ſhall not be moleſted—and you have my honour for your protection.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Bye, Miſs, if there be law or juſtice in England, you ſhan't ſtay long here.

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake tell me, is my ſiſter in this houſe?

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: She is, Madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: May I not ſee her, pray?

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: Not at preſent, Madam; but don't let that diſturb you—I can aſſure you ſhe is well and ſafe.

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: Does my father know where we are?

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Madam, I am not permitted to anſwer your queſtions to your ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: What will become of us!—Thus are my dreams of happineſs vaniſhed—The enraptured ſcenes my fancy drew exiſted but in imagination—now in their ſtead, each way I turn around, nought preſent themſelves but ſhame, deſpair, and infamy!

div.head: ACT IV.
div.stage: EPICENE, WILVILLE, and Sir HARRY TEMPLE.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: MY dear Wilville, I am very much obliged to you for this viſit, I intended calling on you in a few days.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: On me; for what, pray?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Pſha! a triſle—There's a ſubſcription amongſt a few of us men of taſte to raiſe ten thouſand pounds, to divide between three Italian ſingers and two capital French dancers, to be invited over for that purpoſe next winter. That ſum, with what the managers can give, benefits, and a few triſting preſents, will enable them to live tolerably genteel, and oblige foreigners to confeſs that no nation out-does us in generoſity to ſtrangers—Will you make one?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: I can't ſay that I have the leaſt inclination, and muſt think half that ſum beſtow'd on natives of merit and character, wou'd be infinitely more laudable.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: May I renounce every thing that's foreign if I think ſo—for in my opinion, a man cannot give a greater proof of the remains of old Engliſh barbariſm, than by encouraging natives, let their merit be ever ſo deſerving—'tis as great a vulgariſm, and as much out of faſhion, as relieving the poor of the pariſh one lives in.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: I ſhan't diſpute the matter with you now, having buſineſs, to us, or much greater moment—You know Lord Promiſe?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Who, George?—perfectly, few know him better—He juſt parted from me—

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: As I gueſs'd— (to Temple)—Did he mention what occaſion'd his return to town ſo ſoon?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p:
Oh, now I ſuſpect what you are about—You want to ſhare the ſpoil—Ay, I know the whole ſtory
—Two damn'd fine girls he brought up with him. When he's tired, I ſuppoſe, he intends introducing them on the town.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: The town, Sir!—That the villain dares not.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Hold, Temple, reſtrain the impetuoſity of your temper.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Confound my intellects! if there is not ſome myſtery in this affair!

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, there is a myſtery which you muſt unravel, or I ſhall have recourſe to diſagreeable methods to oblige you.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Tom, is your friend apt to be lunatic?—For bubble me at Arthur's, if I underſrand a ſyllable he ſays.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: No trifling, Sir; inform me where the ladies are this inſtant, or give me immediate ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, Sir! I'll give you every reaſonable ſatisfaction you can deſire—But for fighting you muſt excuſe me, as I think it damn'd unreaſonable!

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Put up! here comes Promiſe in right time to anſwer for himſelf.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Epicene! I want to—Who the devil are theſe!

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you are Lord Promiſe?

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: I am, Sir—Give me leave to demand your •• me?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Temple.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: I have not the honour of knowing you.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: I believe we ſhall be better acquainted before we part.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Very poſſible.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Give me leave to aſk, my Lord, what you have done with the Lambton Family?

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: The Lambton Family!

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, 'tis a plain queſtion, and requires an immediate anſwer.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Firſt, Sir, let me know who you are, that in this peremptory manner demands it?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: One that is determin'd to make you render a ſtrict account of them.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Indeed!—I will then—They are under my protection.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Reſtore them directly to their liberty.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: I will not.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: You ſhall.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Who dares attempt to make me!

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: And I!

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: What! do you intend to aſſaſſinate me? But were you arm'd an hundred fold, thus I defy you—

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I ſcorn the thought.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Gentlemen! for heaven's ſake be calm!—What the devil's the matter?—Will nothing content ye but cutting one another's throats?—I'm ſure if you had the averſion to blood I have, you'd be peaceable enough.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Give up the ladies, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: You ſhall have my life firſt.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: You muſt defend it well, or I will—Meet me to-morrow morning at ſix in the park, there to decide our differences.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Depend upon me.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: No, 'tis I who have moſt reaſon, and muſh inſiſt on ſatisfaction firſt.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Patience, Gentlemen!—One at a time—Let me diſpatch one firſt, and then I ſhall chaſtize the inſolence of the other at my leiſure.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Be not too ſure—Meet me with a ſecond at the time appointed.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: May an eternal ſtigma brand my name if I diſappoint you!

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Till then farewel!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: By all that's terrible! I am glad they are gone, for I was curſedly afraid they wou'd have turn'd their fury upon me.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Who are theſe mettleſome ſparks?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I know but one of them, Wilville—The other fiery one, I believe, is Sir Harry Temple.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: I have heard of them both, but cannot imagine by what unlucky accident they came to the knowledge of theſe girls—Epicene, I am going to do you great honour.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Well, let's hear.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: You ſhall be my ſecond in this affair.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Sink me into everlaſting oblivion, if I will!

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: You cannot be in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I am, by all that's ſerious!

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: What's your reaſon?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: George, you are a man of courage, and theſe affairs may be an amuſement to you—I, on the contrary, have an averſion to a ſword out of its ſcabbard, much more to its being lodg'd in my body.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Then you poſitively refuſe?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: If ever I draw a ſword again, after my late diſaſter, except it be to break a lamp, frighten a waiter, or pink an old woman, where I am ſure my courage will not be put to the trial, may I never retaſte the life-giving air of the continent.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: You are a contemptible fellow, below my anger—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Hearkee, Promiſe, another word of comfort, Major Standfield is in town—What, fight him too?

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Very poſſible—I confeſs I have work enough upon my hands at preſent—But there is no • etreating, and I dare do any thing but think.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: May I be deſpis'd by every perſon of faſhion if this fighting, even when there's a reaſonable occaſion, is not the moſt ridiculous thing in nature!

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: A lady below ſtairs, Sir, deſires to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: A lady to ſee me!—Who is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I can't tell, Sir.

sp.speaker: Epi. Qu'elle entre
sp.p: —Shew her up— Exit. Ser. What buſineſs can a lady poſſibly have with me!—Here ſhe comes—Umph!—Veil'd!—a foreigner by her air.

sp.speaker: Epi. Vous plait il de vous aſſoir
sp.p: —Madam, your moſt obedient—Pleaſe to be ſeated—I think myſelf greatly honour'd by this viſit—Pray, may I have the favour of knowing what has occaſion'd it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Oh! Sir!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Pity my confuſion—and—and—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: And what, Madam?

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Spare the bluſhes which force themſelves even thro' this veil of ſhame!

sp.speaker: Epi. Ah Bella Donzella
sp.p: —Heyday!—A fine girl by all that's delicate, and confoundedly in love with me, or I am greatly miſtaken!— (aſide)—Compoſe yourſelf, my dear, you have nothing to be alarm'd at—May I be electrified by your charms, if I am not a man of the niceſt honour—Withdraw that cloud, and throw yourſelf wholly on my protection.

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: O! theſe well-known ſounds!—But I will rely on your generoſity, and reveal my hapleſs ſtory—Behold this face— (unveiling)—then judge of my unhappy deſtiny!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Whither does all this tend to!

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Think how ſevere muſt be my reflections, when, impell'd by love, I forſake relations, friends, country, every tender tie of nature and affection, and ſacrifice them all for your dear, dear ſake!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: For mine, Madam?—May I be offer'd up a victim on the altar of Venus, if I can comprehend the meaning of all this!

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Do you not know me then?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Never ſaw you before, to my knowledge—Strike me blind if I did!

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Then I am irremediably undone!—Unkind Epicene! thus to ſlight a maid who adores you.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, where do you ſay I have had that pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Have not you been in Italy?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Were you not intimate at Piſa with the noble family of Bentivolio?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I was, Madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Do you not remember they were once viſited by their neice, Julia?—I am that unhappy maid—At firſt ſight I lov'd, and time has only ſerved to confirm me in my hopelſs flame—I wrote, but virgin-modeſty forbad my ſending it—At laſt, hearing of your return to England, the long-ſuppreſs'd paſſion grew too violent to be conceal'd—I reſolv'd to follow you—eſcap'd from my friends—brav'd all the perils of ſo long a voyage, and am now come to caſt myſelf at your feet, there to receive the reward of my conſtancy, or, at once, put an end to my ſufferings—

sp.speaker: Epi
sp.p: I am petrified with aſtoniſhment!—Riſe, Madam—

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Not till your cruel heart is ſoftned!—By letters from a friend, who was privy to my flight, I am inform'd my brother, to whoſe care I was entruſted on my parents death, has traced my ſteps to England, nay, is this very moment in London, in ſearch of me, perhaps entering this houſe, when, ſuch is • is impetuous temper, and refin'd notions of honour, that your life will be in danger from his reſentment, and immediate death muſt be my portion.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What an unlucky affair this is!—Riſe, for heaven's ſake, Madam!

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Never—here will I cling 'till I've won you to pity me!

sp.speaker: Clement.—(within)—
sp.p: 'Tis falſe!—I know ſhe's here, and will have vengeance!

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Oh gracious!—my brother's voice!—What will be the conſequence!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: The devil it is!—Let me entreat you to riſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: No, cruel, obdurate man!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Confuſion!—then my fears are true!—Have I at laſt found thee, thou ſhame to thy ſex?—As for you, villain, draw, and deſend your unworthy life.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, I beſeech you hold!—May I be condemn'd to everlaſting infamy, if I am not entirely innocent in this affair!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Innocent!—but I waſte time in parlying with ſuch a wretch—draw, or this inſtant is your laſt.

sp.speaker: Epl.
sp.p: Help! murder! help!

sp.speaker: Cle.—(preſenting a piſtol)—
sp.p: Another ſuch word and you are a dead man.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I'm afraid I am a dead man indeed—For pity's ſake, Madam, convince your brother of his miſtake.

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Alas, Sir! what can I ſay?—He will believe nothing from me; you had beſt own the truth.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I ſee your guilt confounds you—Is this the grateful return you make to ſuch unmerited acts of hoſpitality and kindneſs?—to ſeduce the niece of ſo noble a houſe—a houſe that prides itſelf on the purity of its blood, and the number of princes allied to it. Could not the largeneſs of her fortune tempt you to demand her honourably in marriage, without having recourſe to ſuch baſe methods?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Eternal ſtupefaction ſeize me, if I am not ſo ſurpriz'd at this whole affair, that I have not power to anſwer.

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Hard-hearted Epicene, ſo long to reſiſt the entreaties of one that loves as I do—Accept my hand and fortune—perhaps my brother kindly will forgive all errors paſt.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Well, Sir, what ſay you to that?—now I'll put your honour to the utmoſt proof—If I oblivionize
all former failings, are you willing to do her juſtice?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Really, Sir, if you'll allow me to ſpeak without offending you, I muſt ſay that this whole tranſaction is a perfect riddle to me—for if I knew any thing of you, her, or her honour, 'till this inſtant, may I be confin'd and embalm'd alive!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Then ſince you trifle, your doom is ſeal'd.

sp.speaker: Epi.—Aſpettate un momento!—
sp.p: Will nothing elſe content you but my marrying this lady?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: You are ſure you have an unconquerable affection for me?—

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: I think I have given ſufficient proofs of it.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Curſe your proofs and you too, my dear— (aſide)—You promiſe, if I marry this lady, I ſhall poſſeſs her fortune, which you ſay is ample?—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Without doubt.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: And you, Madam, promiſe, that immediately after marriage you will, according to the preſent faſhionable mode, provide yourſelf with a Ciceſbeo?

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: you may depend upon it.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Some comfort that— (aſide)—I ſhall be permitted to reſide in any part of Italy I pleaſe, no matter how far diſtant from my lady here—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nothing more reaſonable.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p:
As I ſhall give you an unlimited liberty, Ma
•• m, to have what friends you pleaſe at your petite
• uppers, or elſewhere, you, on your part, promiſe not to take it ill if in public or private I always treat you with the polite coldneſs and indifference of a huſband?

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: O, by no means, I do not wiſh to appear particular, and I am ſenſible that hardly any thing but the name of marriage exiſts now.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Nor you, Sir, when the harmleſs frolic takes you, be for cutting my throat again?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Umph!—Why, on my ſiſter's account, I ſhall forego that pleaſure,

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Since the devil will have me married, I think I cou'd not have had more reaſonable terms.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Give me your hand, now I find you are a man of honour.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Oh, zounds! I had forgot—I am engag'd already.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How, Sir?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I am, by all that's miſerable!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Very well, Sir—you know the conſequence.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What an unfortunate creature am I!—But hear me—I am already engag'd to marry another lady, or forfeit thirty thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A trifle!—forfeit it.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: My fortune will not enable me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: My ſiſter's ſhall—Come, ſince I find words will not bind you, ſtronger ties ſhall—ſit down, write your conſent to marry my ſiſter, under penalty of loſing your whole eſtate.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Dear Sir, this is ſuperlatively cruel!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No alternative—this or that—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: O that I durſt fight!—Well, I muſt ſubmit— (ſits down to write)—Your name, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What, don't you know that already?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: No, curſe me if I do!

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Julia Bentivolio.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Julia Bentivolio— (writes)—Umph—umph—there, Sir—will that ſatisfy you?

sp.speaker: Cle.—(reads)—
sp.p: I promiſe—umph—marry—Julia Bentivolio—forteiture whole fortune—John Epicene—ay, ay, this will do—Now, ſiſter, I give you leave to embrace your huſband.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Huſband!—What harmony in the name!

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.—(embracing Epicene)—
sp.p: With rapture do I fold the darling of my wiſhes!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Zounds! my dear, not ſo violent in your embraces!—'tis the moſt unfaſhionable thing in nature.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I am ſorry to interrupt your bliſs, but, Julia, you muſt retire with me, if the ardency of your paſſion will allow you to live a few hours without her.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Wou'd I had never ſeen her!—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I expect, Sir, you'll give immediate orders for the ſolemnization of your nuptials—and not to delay your happineſs by unneceſſary preparations, I kindly intend to celebrate them this evening.

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Now, brother, you are kind indeed!—Adieu, my beſt beloved!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Adieu, my future torment!—Married!—no, I'll hang myſelf out of the way, and at once prevent my troubles!—And yet I have not the heart to deprive the world of ſuch a pattern of elegance and dreſs—What, if I diſpute this conſent at law, as forc'd and illegal?—yes, and perhaps have myſelf run thro' the body before its determin'd—No, I muſt be married—deviliſh hard luck!—Oh, my unfortunate ſtars!—to what a dilemma am I reduced—either to fight or marry.

div.stage: SCENE, another Apartment in Epicene's Houſe.
Enter Lord PROMISE, and Miſs SPENCE.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Come, no more whining—have not I agreed to the ſiſters being together at your requeſt? what wou'd you be at?—is there any harm done to them?

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: No, but how long will they remain ſo?

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: As long as I am maſter of my paſſions, not a bit longer—I think I have had an uncommon ſhare of patience in this affair—for ſuch a perverſe obſtinate baggage I never before met with.

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: Happy wou'd our ſex be, if all, like her. were proof againſt the falſe attacks of perjur'd, faithleſs men.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p:
Better as it is, child—You wou'd then be too near perfection for us mere frail mortals to approach—Go, go, imitate your betters, think of repentance when you paſt the power of ſinning. Exit. Miſs Spence.
Enter VARNISH. Well, Varniſh, our ſchemes hitherto have proved abortive—You are almoſt preach'd into a reformee by a grey-headed old man—and I have been fairly foiled by a green girl—What a couple of curſed fools!—This conſcience is a plaguy troubleſome companion.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: Ah, my Lord, we never can do any good while we liſten to it.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: You muſt to Mr. Lambton again—tempt him once more—offer any terms you pleaſe—tell him the deed is done—try, if poſſible, to perſuade him to write to his daughter that he approves of it—that may go a great way with her—about it directly. I ſhall wait your return before I attempt any thing further.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: How if I don't ſucceed?

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Aſk me no queſtions, Varniſh—I am almoſt diſtracted—Sure never was ſo ſtrange a compound of love, libertiniſm, generoſity, and honour!

div.stage: SCENE, Another Apartment in the ſame Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am, however, glad, Charlotte, that your eyes are at laſt opened to ſee the fallacy of your wild ideas.

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: Say no more, ſiſter, I am heartily aſham'd and mortified already—I begin to ſee things in a new light, but my experience had like to have coſt me dear.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Enough, my dear, to be ſenſible of having acted wrong, is pain ſufficient to the ingenious mind, therefore I have done—What do you think of our
preſent ſituation?—for my part—but we are interrupted—

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: Ladies, if you'll pleaſe to walk into the next room tea is ready.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Excuſe us, Madam; in the preſent perturbation of our minds, refreſhment is not worth a thought.

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: I am ſenſible, ladies, the part I have acted in this affair muſt make me appear odious in your eyes, as it has contemptible in my own, yet, if you will but hear me—

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: Too much have we heard already, to be any longer impos'd upon.

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: Believe me, I do not mean it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh, vice! what power has thou attain'd, when thou wear'ſt the ſemblance that virtue us'd to pride in!—A form like yours, ſurely, never was deſign'd to be an inſtrument in a ſcheme ſo deteſtable.

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: Abhorr'd be the hour I ever was!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If I can read aright, you are not one of thoſe who are harden'd in the ways of guilt—Your appearance ſpeaks you ſprung from parents who wou'd hide their heads in ſhame at your unhappy conduct—Have you unwarily deviated from the paths of virtue? add not to your crimes by endeavouring to make others equally wretched.

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: What ſhall I ſay to gain belief?—Appearances, I own, are ſtrong againſt me—but black as I may ſeem, hear but my melancholy ſtory, and then refuſe me pity if you can.

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: Proceed, and be aſſured we wiſh to find it ſo.

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p:
Behold before you the only, and once prided daughter, of an ancient happy couple, as Love and Hymen ever yet united—to myſelf alone I owe my ruin—unmindful of their precepts, and truſting in the force of my imaginary charms, I fell unthinkingly in the fatal ſnare laid by the moſt artful
of men—Lord Promiſe triumph'd over my innocence—To conceal my ſhame, I left my tender parents, and ventur'd into the world deſtitute of fortune, friends, or virtue!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Unhappy conſequences of one falſe ſtep!

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: Fatally ſo, indeed!—Deſerted, deſpis'd, and hateful to myſelf, I cou'd only have recourſe to the author of my ruin—for a while he behav'd with tenderneſs, cool indifference ſucceeded, and I was ſoon oblig'd to give place to newer objects—What cou'd I do? my dependance was ſolely upon him—I bore my fate with reſignation, conſcious of having deſerv'd it, but when he oblig'd me to act a part in your deception, my remorſe grew too violent to be ſtifled—Thank heav'n he has hitherto fail'd in his deſigns—and I am now come with a determin'd reſolution either to effect your deliverance, or ſhare your fate while you remain here.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then we have ſtill ſome hopes, and providence has not yet deſerted us!—But what's to be done? how get from theſe unhallow'd walls?

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: That will be a difficult taſk▪ I am afraid, guarded as you are by his watchful emiſſaries.

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: Pray, do you know Sir Harry Temple?

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nor a Mr. Wilville?

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: I can't recollect that I do.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, if you did, 'twou'd be to no purpoſe, they, alas! are many miles from hence—all hopes of relief from them are vain—But do you know Lord Promiſe's Siſter?

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: I have ſlight knowledge of her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I believe ſhe will be the only probable means of our delivery—Suppoſe you throw yourſelf upon her generoſity—confeſs your whole affecting ſtory, and relate our cruel detention—I think, if her breaſt be not totally void of every feminine virtue, ſhe will pity you, and protect us.

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: Alas, Madam, Iſcarce can gather courage to approach her; yet to releaſe you, and in ſome meaſure atone for paſt offences, I wou'd ſubmit to any thing, however humiliating.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then let me perſuade you to go thither.

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I will.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But this inſtant—conſider our ſituation—a moment's delay may put it out of her power to relieve us.

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: I'll go directly—in the mean time pray take a diſh of tea, and recruit your exhauſted ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You'll return as ſoon as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Miſs Spen.
sp.p: Depend upon it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come, ſiſter, let us endeavour to compoſe ourſelves, and call to mind that from adverſity oft ſpring our choiceſt bleſſings.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: My daughters not yet return'd, nor any news of Lord Promiſe!—I am almoſt diſtracted! Enter VARNISH. Oh, Sir, you are come—well—now I hope my fears are over—Where are my children?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: Safe, Sir; very ſafe, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: My bleſſing on you for the news!—May I not expect them home ſoon?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: Why, Sir, they have been ſo agreeably entertain'd ſince they went abroad, that you muſt not 〈◊〉 impatient if they don't return quite ſo ſoon as you expected.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: My poor girls!—they have indeed ſeen very little of the world, nor have they any thing to recommend them to the company they are in, except it be their innocence and virtue.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p:
Really, Mr. Lambton, you have reaſon to be proud of them—they charm every one with their behaviour—Lady Fanny loves them already like ſiſters, nay, ſhe ſays it will be their own faults, if
they do not always rank ſo in her eſteem, as her happineſs is wound up in theirs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: Her goodneſs is too much, too much for ſuch unworthy objects—for how is it poſſible they can contribute to her happineſs?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: I have told you, Sir, how violently fond my Lord is of Miſs Maria—every minute encreaſes his paſſion, and it is now arriv'd at ſuch a pitch, that he cannot live an hour without her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: Live an hour without her!—You cannot mean it, ſure?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, I do—You are a happy man, Mr. Lambton, to be father to ſo beautiful a daughter!—make yourſelf perfectly eaſy—your fortune is made for ever.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: Oh, wou'd to heav'n I cou'd!—For goodneſs ſake, Sir, explain your dark ambiguous meaning.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: I am come, Sir, to congratulate you on the happy change of your affairs—Lord Promiſe has already obtain'd a vacant place of two hundred pounds a year for you; Miſs Maria has five hundred pounds yearly ſettled upon her during life, beſides houſe, equipage, ſervants, and—

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: How!—hold, for the love of charity! On what conditions were all theſe things obtain'd?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: Conditions! none, Sir—Lord Promiſe is too generous to exact any—all he deſires in return, is to be aſſur'd of Miſs Maria's unalterable love and conſtancy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: Merciful powers! how is my old agonizing heart torn by a thouſand different emotions! If you have any humanity in you, anſwer me truly—Are my Lord's deſigns upon my daughter honourable, or not?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: Entirely, Sir, upon my credit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: I wiſh I may find them ſo.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p:
'Tis true, it is not in his power to marry her; what of that, you cannot ſurely be ſo weak and blind
to your own intereſt, as to ſtand on mere punctilio? In every other reſpect ſhe will be more than his wife—and as to—

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: Stop your licentious tongue! nor dare to inſult the virtuous poverty of my white hairs!

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: Inſult, Sir! the fartheſt thing in the world from my thoughts—Can you term it inſult to be at once ſeated above the—

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: Thou pander—look on me well—conſider whom you tempt—a father—Then think, whether worlds ought to bribe me to deviate a moment from my duty.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: But, allowing your ſentiments their utmoſt weight, will you not patiently bear an evil which cannot be removed?

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: What, more myſtery!—Pray, pray explain yourſelf, and let me know the worſt of my unhappy fate.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: Miſs Maria, Sir, not ſo inſenſible of my Lord's favours, has kindly rewarded him with every return in her power to beſtow.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: Then all is over!—break heart-ſtrings, break at once, and end this miſerable being!— (walking about diſorder'd)—Yet, 'tis, it muſt be falſe!—Her mind, pure and ſpotleſs as new-drifted ſnow, cou'd not ſo ſoon be tainted—No, my child you cou'd not, wou'd not ſell your innocence, nor part with that jewel of ineſtimable price!

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: To what end, Sir, ſhou'd I now impoſe on you?—Your daughter has accepted of my Lord's love and tenderneſs—ſhe now has ſent me to requeſt you'd make yourſelf eaſy at what has happen'd, and, as ſoon as your firſt emotions are over, will be glad to ſee you; in the mean time, if you will write her word that you are ſatisfied with her conduct, and happy, ſhe will be compleatly ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p:
Tantalize not ſuch a wretch as me with the name of happineſs!—Oh, cruel, cruel girl, thus to pierce the boſom of a tender, doting father!
May every—no, I will not curſe her—curſe, where I ſo many thouſand times have bleſs'd—'twou'd be unnatural—Let then the never-ceaſing ſting of conſcience at laſt work her to repentance—Where is ſhe? lead me to her, that if ſhe has any ſpark of virtue yet remaining in her, I may awaken it—

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: Hold, Sir—that at preſent is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: Impoſſible, Sir!—What power ſhall hinder me?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: I muſt, Sir—in compaſſion to your mind thus agitated, I muſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: Compaſſion, ſaid'ſt thou?—if thou haſt the leaſt tincture of it in thy compoſition, have pity on a wretched father, born down with age and ſorrows—torture me not in this manner, 'tis too much for my feeble nature long to ſupport—let me but ſee my children, and I ſhall be eaſier.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: To-morrow you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: To-morrow's an age to one in doubt like me—Stranger as I am, I'll find my way to Lady Fanny's.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.p: Your efforts are vain—this houſe you are confin'd in, till you have a proper ſenſe of my Lord's kindneſs, and agree to his propoſals—Your daughters, tho' very ſafe, are not at his ſiſter's, nor can your utmoſt diligence find them out—I'll leave you an hour to conſider of this affair—Either accept the offers to make you and your children happy for life, or be oblig'd to return into the country to-morrow morning without them—

Stay! for mercy's ſake ſtay!—Kill me, but do not aſk me to be acceſſary to my children's diſhonour!Exit. Var. He's gone—O, Charlotte!—Maria!—The comforts of my declining years at once torn from me!—and in ſuch a manner—condemn'd to everlaſting infamy—'tis too much!—Unhappy, poor old man! who now will cloſe thy eyes, and receive thy dying bleſſing? O, where are all my dreams of felicity!—thoſe days
I hop'd to ſpend amongſt the prattling liſpers of my daughters!—all vaniſh'd, and real anguiſh now ſucceeds—I dare not think—it may be dangerous— (going)—Yet, ſomething whiſpers comfort to my wounded ſoul—I will, if poſſible, be patient, and put my confidence in that being who never fails to ſuccour the afflicted heart in the hour of calamity!

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: Enter Lady FANNY and Miſs CLEMENT.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: HA! ha! ha!—Upon my word, Lucy, you have manag'd this affair admirably, beyond my expectations—We ſhall now proceed to the ſecond part of the ſcene, and if we don't torment him to ſome purpoſe, why I am greatly deceived.

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Never fear, I'll ſecond you—But you can't imagine how I'm affected with Miſs Spence's relation of the Miſs Lambtons confinement.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Not more than I am, I aſſure you—poor girls! I am impatient 'till we go to their relief.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Two Gentlemen, my Lady, Sir Harry Temple and Mr. Wilville, deſire to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Hey-day! more adventures!—Wait on them up— Exit. Ser. What can they want with me? ſomething relating to my righteous brother, I ſuppoſe—I muſt beg of you, my dear, to retire for a minute or two, and as ſoon as theſe gentlemen are gone, we'll proceed to Epicene's together.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Pardon this intruſion, my Lady, which no thing but the nature of our buſineſs cou'd excuſe.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: There needs none, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Neceſſity, Madam, obliges us, after every other method has fail'd, to trouble you—We are in ſearch of two ladies, whom your brother has decoy'd up to twon, and by force ſecretes, ſpite of our utmoſt endeavours to ſind out and releaſe them.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: I was right I find— (aſide)—Your ſearch is at an end, Gentlemen, if you mean Mr. Lambton's family, who came to town this morning.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: We do—Is it poſſible you can have heard of them?

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: I have, and was contriving means for their deliverance when you came in.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: How fortunate!—Dear Lady, let us fly to give them liberty, and prevent the evils they are threatned with.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Hold, Sir; not ſo faſt—truſt all to my management, and I'll enſure you ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: You ſhall be our tutelar deity on this occaſion, only conſider our impatience.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: I do, therefore will not waſte time in uſeleſs ceremonies—do you know Epicene?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Perfectly well.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: You muſt accompany me thither directly, on our way I'll explain every thing, and give you proper inſtructions how to behave.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Lead on, Madam, and may our ſucceſs exceed our wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Strike me deaf at an opera, Promiſe, if ever I was in ſuch a dilemma before!—No, not even in Naples, when that curſed affair happen'd which forced me to live a month with Squalitini the burletta ſinger.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: And ſo the brother abſolutely obliged you to ſign a contract.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Abſolutely; for, when his ſword was drawn, had he inſiſted on my binding myſelf to a tobacco planter, to work in his plantations the remainder of my life, I cou'd not have refuſed him.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: What a ſpiritleſs dog!—Well, but was the Signiora handſome?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p:
Deviliſhly ſo—But what was that to me?—Had ſhe the beauty of Venus, the chaſtity of Diana, and the wiſdom of Minerva—all theſe joined together
cou'd not have gained her admiſſion into the Coterie, or let me into the ſecret at the next Newmarket meeting.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Quite the contrary, I believe.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Of what uſe are a woman's good qualities then?—If my deſtiny will have me yoked, give me a faſhionable wife, who will raiſe a man's reputation in the world.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Pray, how is that to be done?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Only by following the example of every day—eloping before the honey-moon is over—obtaining a divorce—and exalting the happy man to a level with the greateſt names of the preſent age.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Very clever indeed.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Oh, almoſt as certain a road to fame as modern patriotiſm—But I have not told you all my miſfortunes—This viſit has deſtroyed an immenſe deal of happineſs I had in petto.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Ay! How ſo?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I intended to have cut a diſtinguiſhing figure at the next maſquerade, in the character of a French milliner.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Which this accident has prevented?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: It has by all that's cruel!—For what Guſto cou'd I have, or how cou'd I poſſibly diſplay my talents under ſuch an embarraſſment?

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: True—The world will ſuſtain an irreparable loſs—But what do you think my ſiſter will ſay to you upon this occaſion?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: May I be annihilated! if that does not giv • me the greateſt concern—She's a lady of the niceſt diſcernment, and if ſhe has unalterably fix'd her affections on me, ſo as to drive her to ſome act of deſperation, I ſhou'd never forgive myſelf.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Lady Fanny Promiſe deſires to ſpeak with you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Shew her up.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Your ſiſter!—Zounds, what ſhall I do?—I am quite unprepar'd for this rencontre.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Faith, ſo am I; her coming, I am afraid, bodes no good to either of us—retire you, and leave me to manage her.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: My dear boy, help me out of this difficulty, and command me to eternity.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: She has not ſure got a hint of what I am about, if ſhe has, I muſt ſhift ground directly.

div.stage: Enter Lady FANNY and Miſs CLEMENT.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Brother, I am glad to ſee you.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: That's more than I can ſay by you— (aſide) Siſter, your ſervant—What, my little rogue Clement!—I'll lay my life ſome miſchief's on foot now, for no other cauſe cou'd have brought you both hither.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: You are a prophet, brother—Come, tell us now whether we ſhall ſucceed or no?

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Where two women join their heads together, I think they are a match for the grand miſchief maker.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Thank you!—You had beſt take care of yourſelf— (aſide)—Pray, where is that pretty gentleman, your travelling companion?

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Who, Epicene?

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: The fame.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Somewhere in the houſe, I ſuppoſe—Is your buſineſs with him?

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p:
It is, and we are come to beg your aſſiſt
• nce.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Only to plague him a little.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Poor devil! he's pretty well prepar'd to your hand, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: How! has he told you of his whimſical ſituation?

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: We were juſt talking of it when you interrupted us—but, how the deuce came you to know it?

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Becauſe I contriv'd it.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: You contriv'd it!

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Yes—behold the diſtreſs'd Lady Julia Bentivolio.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—Upon my ſoul a glorious joke! ha! ha! ha!—Is it poſſible he can be ſo duped?—Well, what am I to do?

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Withdraw 'till a convenient time, then appear, and add to his diſtreſs, by inſiſting on the performance of his contract with me.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! excellent!—I underſtand you—you cou'd not have oblig'd me more highly than by letting me into the ſecret—ha! ha! ha!—If I don't mortify him—

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Away then, and ſend him up—but not the leaſt hint of what we are about.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: No, not for the world.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: And when that's over, my good brother, I ſhall take you to taſk in a manner you little ſuſpect. I think my plans are pretty well laid now, and can hardly fail of ſucceſs—This confiding in him, lulls him to perfect ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Well, what am I to do?

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Retire to your brother, but place yourſelves within hearing, and when you think your preſence neceſſary, both ſecond me, and join in the attack—Stay, take my laſt orders—when I have done with Epicene, and begun upon my brother, do you march off unperceiv'd, and lead up the reinforcements in regular order.

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Never fear me—this will be a curious piece of generalſhip.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Ay, girl; and, if we ſucceed, we ſhall deſerve ſtatues raiſing to our memories—march.

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Row, dow! dow! dow! row! dow!

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Bravo!—mum!—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Dear Lady Fanny, this is ſo great an honour—

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: And, I am afraid, ſo unwiſh'd for—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Wrong not your own charms ſo far as to imagine I wiſh not to devote my whole life to their contemplation.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: But it muſt be at a diſtance tho', I find—Come, come, Mr. Epicene, 'tis in vain to diſguiſe my unhappy fate, tho' your politeneſs won'd gloſs it over—be ingenuous, and confeſs you have not a heart to beſtow.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Alas, Lady Fanny, our affections are not to be commanded—if they were, I ſwear by all that's beautiful, I know not a more deſerving object.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: O feeble, weak attractions!—they cannot hold in chains the only man I ever wiſh'd to conquer!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, this is very diſtreſſing!

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Yet, who can behold that aſſemblage of every thing noble and manly, without pitying, rather than condemning the violence of my unreturn'd affection!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Far gone, by all that's affecting!—And yet what a proper ſenſe ſhe entertains of my merit!

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Not a word to give me hopes!—Sure if I lay aſide the native modefty of my ſex, the object before me will ſufficiently juſtify me to the world—You muſt, nay, you ſhall comply.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Egad, if I don't take care, ſhe may go greater lengths than I deſire— (aſide)—Believe me, Lady Fanny, an unlucky accident has render'd it utterly impoſſible for me to do you the juſtice you deſerve—notwithſtanding I love, nay, adore you more than any of your ſex.—
sp.stage: [During this ſpeech Miſs Clement ſteals ſoftly in, and at the end takes one of his hands, Lady Fanny the other.]

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Except me, Mr. Epicene!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Confuſion!—what will become of me!

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Why does my love turn away?—What woman's this, who ſeems to take an intereſt in you?

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: One, Madam, that has a prior claim to you, and is reſolv'd to aſſert it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Indeed!—this is ſome artifice—I ſee thro' the weak device, and will ſoon defeat it—brother!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: The brother!—this is too much!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Mr. Epicene, I am very glad to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I wiſh with all my heart I could return the compliment.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I am come rather ſooner than I at firſt intended; but when I conſider'd the violence of your paſſion for my ſiſter, I cou'd no longer retard your happineſs.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: You are too good!—too good, upon my ſoul!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well, Sir, ſhall the ceremony be immediately per • orm'd?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: If the ceremony at tyburn was perform'd, I ſhou'd have a happy riddance from my plagues!

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: I know not what right, Sir, you, or that lady has to my huſband.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Your huſband!—How, Sir, are you married to that lady?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: No, Sir—not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Oh, well—are you ready and willing to marry my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Very ready, Sir—but curſedly unwilling!

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Nay, then, I muſt have recourſe to other means—O brother! brother! come and right an injur'd ſiſter!

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: My ſiſter! why do you call in this alarming manner?

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: I'm wrong'd, baſely wrong'd, and have not the leaſt hopes of redreſs, except from you.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: For the love of charity, Promi • e, come and right me—'tis I have moſt need of it.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: What's the reaſon of this confuſion?—Who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Carlino Bentivolio—brother to this lady.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Ay, George, this is the damn'd fierce Italian who bully'd me ſo to-day—I wiſh'd for you then.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Well, ſiſter—to you—

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: I claim my contract.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: You are determined to urge your claim?

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Lookee, Epicene, I profeſs myſelf your friend—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: A thouſand thanks, my dear boy?

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: And as a proof of my friendſhip, I will this inſtant—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What? what?

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Sacrifice you, unleſs you do my ſiſter juſtice.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Oh, mercy on me!

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: This moment agree to marry her, or immediate death's your portion.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I will—I will!

sp.speaker: Cle.—(drawing)—
sp.p: How, Sir? have not you promiſed this lady that ſatisfaction?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Yes, I have—I am diſtracted between them! Really, gentlemen, I am but a man, if you expect to find me more, you'll be deviliſhly miſtaken—If I can oblige the ladies, I will—only determine between yourſelves whether I muſt marry one or both of them, and I ſhall obey you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I ſee you are almoſt below my notice.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I wiſh I was entirely ſo.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: I find I muſt be an umpire in this affair—Come, Epicene, if you wiſh to be deliver'd from your thraldom, you muſt make ſome humiliating conceſſions.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Heav'n knows, any thing that's in my power, I will.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: In the firſt place, you muſt aſk pardon of theſe ladies, and, thro' them, of the whole ſex, for the cold unanimated, unworthy ideas, you always entertain's of thoſe maſter-pieces of nature.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Next, you muſt acknowledge you have not courage enough to attempt, nor ſenſe ſufficient to prize, the leaſt of their favours.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I acknowledge.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: You muſt now ſay after me—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: L. Pro. (Epicene repeating after him)
sp.p: I confeſs, that a Macaroni is the moſt inſignificant—inſipid—uſeleſs—contemptible being—in the whole creation—Very well, you are docile, I find—Laſtly, you muſt entirely quit the appearance of ſuch a deſpicable ſpecies, and endeavour to aſſume the Man.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: That's hard, nay, I am afraid impoſſible—You may as well bid me ſhake off my exiſtence.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: For ſhame!—Think who you ſprung from, a race of hardy, virtuous, conquering Britons, and bluſh at your own degenerate exotic effeminancy—But I have done, and be aſſur'd, my ſole motive was to ſet you up a glaſs, wherein you might behold a faithful image—As to my ſiſter, I can prevail on her to reſign her right in you—here, exchange bonds, and never preſume to trouble her more.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: If I do, may the combined plagues of Egypt be my portion!

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: It now only remains to ſatisfy that lady.

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Which will be eaſily done, my Lord, here, Sir, is your contract, nor ſhou'd any conſideration unite me to ſo reprehenſible a character.

sp.speaker: L. Pro. L. Fan. Cle.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Strike me to the antipodes, Madam, if I am not heartily oblig'd to you!

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—Come, 'tis time to drop the maſk—Siſter, I wiſh you joy of your deliverance! If I divine aright, you can now beſtow your hand upon a more worthy object—Clement, take her, take what that fooliſh puppy had not underſtanding enough to value.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: You are very obliging, brother—and ſince 'tis ſo, I own he has deſerv'd me—Here, accept my hand; but, have a care, if you repent, I ſhall not ſo eaſily forego my claim as I did to that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: When I do, may I, like him, be the deſerving object of ridicule!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I am thunderſtruck!—what's all this?—is not your name Carlino Bentivolio?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, Sir, my name's Clement, at your ſervice—Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: L. Pro. L. Fan. Miſ Cle.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Nor yours, Madam Julia Bentivolio?

sp.speaker: Miſs Cle.
sp.p: Lucy Clement, if you pleaſe, Sir—Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I perceive I have been moſt egregiouſly bubbled here!—Ladies and Gentlemen, you have been highly diverted at my expence—I own I deſerve it, and begin to ſee my folly—As a proof, give me leave to withdraw for the preſent, and get perfect in the catechiſm you was pleaſed to teach me.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Stay, Mr. Epicene—after your confeſſion, it wou'd be ungenerous to torment you farther—What a great pity 'tis my brother can't be made as ſenſible of his errors, and reform too.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Pray, my good ſiſter, what errors wou'd your great wiſdom correct?

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Only a few triſling ones, brother—ſuch as that humane delight you take in ſuducing the innocent and unwary of our ſex, and thoſe harmleſs conſequences generally attending—

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Stop, child, this is no time for ſuch lectures.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: The beſt time in the world, brother, our auditors are friends, and they, I am ſure, will excuſe my inability.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Madam, go on—he never ſpared me.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p:
In ſhort, your licentiouſneſs is grown to ſuch a pitch, that unleſs providence, out of its great
goodneſs, timely interpoſes and awakens in you a ſenſe of your guilt, you muſt tremble at its juſt puniſhments.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Pſhaw! ſtuff!—have done with this ſermonizing.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Patience, brother, I am only beginning.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Bravo! Lady Fanny!—to him, he begins to flinch already.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: But as example enforces precept, give me leave to illuſtrate my argument.

div.stage: [Goes to the ſide, and returns with Miſs Spence]

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: What can ſhe mean?

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Behold, here is one of the many objects whom you have wantonly plung'd into endleſs miſery.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Miſs Spence! then I am betray'd, and all's over.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: What, confus'd!—chear up, here are more friends— Enter the two Miſs LAMBTONS. Theſe are the two ladies you entruſted to my care—you ſee I can give a very good account of them—they are come to return you thanks for your friendly invitation up to town—you may expect the father ſoon on the ſame errand.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—I believe 'tis my turn to catechize now—Come, aſk pardon of theſe ladies, and of the whole ſex, for the looſe, profligate ideas you always entertain'd of their virtue.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Epicene, you grow troubleſome.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—Nay, Promiſe— [pulling him by the ſleeve]—you was always an apt ſcholar—ſay after me—I confeſs—that a libertine—is the moſt wicked—dangerous—remorſeleſs—lawleſs—abandoned being—in the whole creation.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: What, brother—not a word?

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p:
Yes, ſiſter, many—'tis paſt—the ſtruggle's over, and I will give way to conſcience—That I have been a profeſs'd libertine I own—before you all I own it, but'tis with the ſincereſt regret—To atone
for paſt miſchiefs is impoſſible—a patriarchal life wou'd be too ſhort—I have followed an ignis fatuus, and am bewilder'd in inextricable paths of error—too late the deluſion vaniſh'd—not even an herculean arm can ſave me now from ſinking.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Courage, brother—we muſt not preſume to ſet bounds to infinite mercy.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Of you, ladies, who happily fell not in my ſnares, I entreat forgiveneſs—I beſeech you pardon each offence againſt you and virtue—To Miſs Spence, 'tis not in my power to make atonement in any meaſure adequate to the wrongs I have done her—What can, ſhall be done—I know her circumſtances, and ſhe may depend upon being provided for in ſuch a manner, as, for the future, to ſet her above temptation.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, Promiſe, this is noble—theſe are genuine fruits of reformation.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.—(Temple and Wilville entering)
sp.p: Now, gentlemen, you may appear, and I hope all animoſity between you will be no more remembered.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: More witneſſes of my ſhame!—they are welcome—I deſign'd, gentlemen, to have injur'd you in the tendereſt point, but heaven providentially interpos'd, and turned, what I intended as the blackeſt crime, into the means of future bleſſings.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Mention it not, my Lord—the original generous, tho' miſled heart, when awak'd from its lethargy of vice, oft-times ariſes more bright and active from its late obſcurity.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.—(entering)
sp.p: Where are my children? give me room—I muſt—I will embrace them!—do I once more fold you in my arms!—no force or fraud ſhall ever ſeparate us more!

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: You need not fear it, Sir—I, who alone was author of your ills, ſhall ſtudy to make your life to come one ſeries of continued happineſs—Thou good old man, can'ſt thou forgive the wrongs I've done thee?

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſhou'd ill deſerve the name you honour me with, if I cou'd not only forgive, but bleſs, the worſt of enemies, even as I hope myſelf to be forgiven—and may that power who delights in acts of mercy, further every good and noble thought!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: May I forfeit all pretenſions to reformation, if the old gentleman's benignity won't make me, unfaſhionable as it may appear, viſit the inſide of a church oftener than I have done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.—(to Temple and Wilville)—
sp.p: Gentlemen, I am happy in ſeeing you here ſo unexpectedly—to what fortunate accident do I owe this pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: To the deſire alone, Sir, of ſerving you and theſe ladies—and lucky as we are in meeting with you, give us leave to hope we may participate in the general joy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: If 'tis in my power you may be aſſur'd of it.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: We both have lov'd your daughters ſome time—you muſt have obſerv'd the particularity of our behaviour, as we wiſh'd not to conceal it—our families and fortunes are well known to you—ſince we came hither, they have owned we were not indifferent to them—perhaps a father's authority might—

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: No, Gentlemen, my children ſhall never be commanded into marriage—'tis my duty to adviſe, but not compel them.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: No great compulſion, I'll anſwer, Mr. Lambton—they'd cry their eyes out to be refus'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: What ſay you, girls?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I own, Sir, Mr. Wilville's good qualities have made an impreſſion on me never to be eraſed, and, authorized by you, I will readily give my hand where my heart is irrevocably engag'd.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: That's a good girl—Come, Miſs Lambton, don't let your younger ſiſter out-do you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Lamb.
sp.p: The dread that my paſt behaviour is inexcuſable, has hitherto kept me ſilent—I am conſcious of its impropriety, and have nothing to offer in defence, but my ſimplicity and ignorance of the world.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: You cannot offer a better plea to the thinking heart.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, if you can deſcend to match with girls whoſe virtue is all their portion—

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Name it not, Sir—As the beginning of our love was diſintereſted, ſo ſhall be the completion—They want no addition of fortune, and are in themſelves treaſures beyond what imperial greatneſs cou'd beſtow.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Nobly ſpoken—and now, Mr. Lambton, give me leave to make ſuch a proviſion for you, as ſhall teſtify a proper ſenſe of my paſt conduct, and in which I am certain my father on his return will readily concur.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: How deviliſh generous this love and honour makes people.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: But yet I miſs a faithful ſervant, who ought to ſhare his maſter's joy.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: He well deſerves it—be it my buſineſs to reward him, and for ever diſcard thoſe minions of vice, who too long have prey'd upon me.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Now, brother, you have with a truly noble Spirit acknowledg'd every failing you have been charged with—can you have conſtancy to perſevere?

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: I think ſo

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Nay, I have a ſevere trial yet to come—a fiery ordeal—but you muſt endure it before you can be perfect.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: That I can never be—but in the name of wonder, what new myſtery have you yet to unravel?

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Turn your eyes this way, and view the man who once was proud to call you friend.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Major Standfield!—'tis too much!—I cannot, dare not ſtand his preſence.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: You can, and muſt, brother—he is not come to hurt your mind with keen reproaches, but rather to pour the healing balm of peace into the corroding wounds of vice, which long have rankled in your breaſt.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: No, no, it cannot be—I do not hope forgiveneſs—Major, I bare my breaſt—there is no way but this to expiate guilt like mine.

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: There is, my Lord, a nobler way—a way which earth and heav'n muſt both approve—prepare yourſelf for more wonder.
sp.stage: [Goes out, and returns with his daughter leading her little boy]

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: O, all ye powers! what is it I behold?—Can it be real, or is it the phantom of my Eugenia, riſen from the dead, to ſet my crimes in full array before me?—I muſt, I will embrace it!—Ha! it ſinks!—help to ſupport her—look down ye bright celeſtial inhabitants of glory, and reſtore this injur'd ſaint to life!

sp.speaker: Miſs Stand.—(recovering)—
sp.p: Oh, my Lord, theſe wild effuſions of a heart overpower'd with love and tenderneſs ſpeak well the unreſtrain'd dictates of its owner—but I muſt curb its tranſports—Look here, another object demands your fondeſt care.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Can it be poſſible ſuch happineſs is in ſtore for me! am I father too?

sp.speaker: Maj.
sp.p: You are, my Lord, if you'll own the obligation.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Own it! ay, prouder of that title than to be hail'd an Indian monarch!—My cherub! my little cherub! receive a father's firſt embraces!—Now, my Eugenia, we are met, never to be ſeparated more.

sp.speaker: Miſs Stand.
sp.p:
Hear me, my Lord—That I have lov'd you, nay, that I ſhall continue to do ſo while life keeps her ſeat, is the only excuſe I can offer for my frailty—I have hitherto obey'd my father's will, permit
me now to follow the dictates of my own—Had I my innocence, and was miſtreſs of the untold treaſures of the eaſt—all that the ſun ſurveys in his diurnal round, you ſhou'd be maſter of it—but cover'd with infamy as I am, tho' you cou'd raiſe me to the utmoſt pinnacle where ſtar-crown'd virtue ought to ſit—a conſcious pride wou'd forbid the exaltation.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Zounds! a charming girl! what a pity 'tis ſhe ſhou'd be loſt to the world.

sp.speaker: L. Pro.
sp.p: Is then my dream of bliſs deſtroy'd?—my new-found bleſſing, turn that way, and intercede with your inexorable mother—tell her my peace here and hereafter depends upon her receiving my penitential vows.

sp.speaker: Miſs Stand.
sp.p: My Lord, the honey-dropping tongue of ſeraphic eloquence cannot move me to change my purpoſe—I have now attain'd my utmoſt wiſhes, to ſee you thoroughly ſenſible of your failings, and wou'd fain retire to that peaceful cottage which this event has drawn me from, there, with my little roſelipp'd comforter, paſs my future hours in undiſturbed ſolitude.

sp.speaker: L. Fan.
sp.p: Preſs her no farther, brother—leave it to time—when ſhe is ſufficiently aſſured of your ſteady perſeverance in the paths of rectitude, the love ſhe acknowledges for you may probably induce her at laſt to reward your conſtancy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lamb.
sp.p: Now, Lady Fanny, with your leave, we'll retire and celebrate the ſurprizing events of this happy day, events which muſt fully manifeſt to every boholder, that however virtue may for a time be oppreſt and held in durance, yet is it always the peculiar, and never-deſerted favourite, of rewarding Providence.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.stage: And ſpoke by Mr. CRESSWICK, in the Character of the MACARONI.

sp.l: It matters not, good ſolks, ſay what you will,
Approve, or diſapprove our author's ſkill,
'Tis ſure there muſt be Macaronies ſtill.
For phantom-faſhion leads us by the noſe,
And makes us die for every whim ſhe ſhews.
A coat, a club, a feather, will engage
A genius of the Bon Ton for an age;
Like Newton's ſyſtem, bear th' inventor's name,
And rank him higher in the liſts of fame.
In Engliſh garb, we know, plain common-ſenſe
To modiſh underſtanding gives offence;
And modeſt merit, if perchance one meets,
How awkward creeps the ſtranger thro', the ſtreets!
Whilſt fan-tail'd folly, with Pariſian air,
Commands that homage ſenſe alone ſhou'd ſhare,
The world's ſo macaronied grown of late,
That common mortals now are out of date;
No ſingle claſs of men this merit claim,
Or high, or low, in faith 'tis all the ſame;
For ſee the Doctor, who, with ſapient, wig,
Gold cane, grave phiz, ere while look'd more than big,
With France's foretop decorates his face,
Preſcribes and dreſſes with macaronied grace;
Then ſwears he hates all formal ſtuff,
For gravity in practice is a puff.
The Soldier, once that hardy ſon of arms,
Whoſe ſoul was rouz'd, was fir'd with war's alarms,
Forgets the eminence on which he ſtood,
Whene'er his country call'd, how boil'd his blood!
Reſigns the glory his forefathers won,
And lives Britannia's alienated ſon.
Still lower let us fall for once, and pop
Our heads into a moders Barber's ſhop;
What the reſult? or what behold we there?
A ſet of Macaronies weaving hair.
Such gen'ral folly your attention claims,
And ſatire here at reformation aims;
On me this night exerts its utmoſt ſskill,
Corrects, reforms, and moulds me to its will.
Ye gentle fair, wou'd but ſuch triflers view
〈…〉 pretty ſ • lves, much more in you;
Wou'd they to ſenſe and virtue bend the knee,
Leave to its native ſoil all foppery,
Nature wou'd ceaſe to weep—The godlike plan
Wou'd elevate, in time, un-monkey man,
With hoſpitable ſmiles old britiſh truth
Wou'd warm your beauty, and adorn our youth.
